Potential U.S. intervention in Libya’ civil war is worthy of consideration if it isn’t happening already. One can only wonder what CIA covert activities currently exist there. However, to stand by idly as if all was well under blue skies would be foolish and dangerous.
While originally openly opposed to American intervention in Iraq, I can only applaud neoconservatives if their theories on a liberalized Middle East play true. America was founded on revolution, and romantic theories such as liberty and fraternity ring true in aiding Libyan rebels.
But also is the prospect of a republicanized Middle East where already educated populace can prove to be team partners in the international community. The status quo is supporting dictatorships shifty, inhumane and unpredictable. The alternative is hope for republics, humanized and predictable.
Obama probably isn’t revealing all his intentions. But intervening in Libya provides strong offense, good defense and the promise of a healthier oil market and human rights climate.
It appears the character Mr. Bumble in Charles Dickens' Oliver Twist said it best: "the law is an ass!"

They cannot do the job, their mindset is not right for the times.  It's not even a political matter, it's a common sense matter.  And shame on their selfish hearts for hanging on forever.  It's disgusting and very discouraging.

Question about the Odd Couple: I recently wrote Keith Olbermann about the odd couple entertaining Washington DC. There seems to be a sequel. I addressed this in my book, Sarah Palin vs. Meghan McCain. The second title was John McCain's Legacy, because the future will not look upon his great heroism, his service to the United States of America, but instead his introducing the world to Sarah Palin.

Thus the odd couple is not the lovable Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau from the 1968 comedy film written by Neil Simon. But John McCain and Joe Lieberman.
Whenever John McCain cuts himself shaving, Joe Lieberman seems to bleed for his maverick.
Doesn't it seem like McCain and Lieberman are going to make another run for the White House? Sarah Palin wasn't originally in the plans. Lieberman was to be Vice President on John McCain's ticket, but McCain decided to ditch his wife and date Sarah Palin for a few months. After all, Sarah's marriage isn't full of stability, but McCain threw Lieberman to the curb faster than Charlie Sheen rejecting a prostitute from his life.
Is Joe Lieberman planning to run with John McCain again?

Thomas Chi
Author
Sarah Palin vs Meghan McCain: John McCain's Legacy
Paperback book, July 4, 2009

Once again, the left wing posters here show their true colors of socialism and their lack of knowledge. Anyone who wants to give Carter any credit, give him credit for making our situation worse. He created the Department of Energy during his administration, and our dependence on foreign oil has been increasing ever since. Poster 47 is absolutely correct, it will be decades before alternative energy will be truly viable on a large scale. We need to use the resources we have available now. To those like Bolger who claim the new oil reserves won't be productive, they really need to get out of their little world. Perhaps a trip out to the oil fields in ND, where oil production is booming in the Bakken Formation would change his mind. Not likely, because facts are inconvenient truths. Then there are those like "plus6sigma", who want to nationalize our energy industry. At what point do you just admit you want socialism so those who want to do nothing have the same amount as those who have worked hard their whole life?
For those who claim rising energy costs won't hurt the economy, take off the rose colored glasses. $4.00 gas did a large part to destroy the economy the last time, and it will take a huge toll this time also. Eugene Gorrin's points were just the tip of the iceberg. Everything that is produced and processed uses energy in the process. Everything will cost more, taking dollars out of the pockets of consumers. To the posters who keep talking about raising gas prices even more and forcing many to use public transportation, that is not feasible either in the majority of the country. The US is a vast country, unlike Europe, which has a much denser population covering a much smaller land mass. Instead lets build more nuclear plants and use the reserves we have in this country that are not tapped while we give out incentives to create truly feasible alternative energy sources for our future needs.
By the way, poster 1, Adam, was right. When gas prices rose last time, there was a huge cry blaming Bush for allowing the prices to rise so high and the oil companies making profits. Where is the outrage now? Bush is no longer in office. It is Obama's issue, and he is doing nothing to change it. I just want to see some of the same ones who blamed Bush call out Obama on this.

[ The elephant in the room way before democracy is how to advance standard of living in these Middle Eastern countries. Democracy without jobs and food means nothing but brutal war]

The Europeans, particularly the Brits, are playing a mysterious role. The Brits -- not the Russians or Chinese -- were the first who cast aspersion on the idea of a "no fly zone." The Brits and other Europeans -- except Germany, perhaps --, may prefer a corrupt tyrant to democracy for an oil-rich Libya. A single corrupt tyrant is always easier to blackmail and handle; an open democracy  with a free press is much more difficult to deal with.
So what's the difference between this case and the high-school kid who was denied the free-speech right to display an offensive banner ("Bong Hits for Jesus") across the street from his school?

Mathew Snyder deserved a better ruling from the Supreme Court. America is not well served by the Supreme Court, the most worthless branch of the US government, with appointed-for-life judges who are unaccountable for their decisions. If these judges faced Congressional re-confirmation every 6 years or so, then they could be held responsible for poor decisions such as in Snyder-v-Phelps.

In addition, I don't understand why Americans think that the evil 1st Amendment is something beneficial. For instance, Canada and Australia have no similar law, and yet both nations are better societies with a higher quality of life than the United States. America could use another Constitutional Convention so it can terminate the hideous 1st Amendment, as well as the many other poor laws and undemocratic institutions in the Federal Government. The Federal Government needs a sunset law, so that laws (and existing Constitutional amendments) have to be re-confirmed every 25 years or so by Congress or expire. The Supreme Court would be a good choice for an earliest possible expiration date.

I am a Colombian citizen and I understand the plight of the Peruvian people.  It's heart breaking when people, who really don't understand the complexities of our countries, say they "understand the freedom movement".  How can they understand something that is so foreign to their reality?  From their comfortable apartments in the United States and Europe, in an arrogant manner, they tell us that we don't have "democratically elected governments" and that's why they've "chosen" to come free our people.  Free us from what?  No one has the right to take up arms to kill, extort, kidnap innocent civilians.  Our countries have many problems, no one that more than us, but it's hurtful and disrespectful that because we're developing nations, we must then be “ignorant” and “naïve” about our surroundings.  With this lie, people like Lori Berenson, Tanja Nijmeijer, come to our countries and become involved in way over their heads.  I feel for her son, but these “freedom fighters” deserve whatever happens to them.

She was foolish, naive, simplistic and overly idealistic like many people when they are young. But not so many have had to pay such a terrible price for their lack of judgment. She has paid dearly already, more dearly than any of us can possibly imagine. I hope she can live the remaining years of her sentence in Peru in peace, and finally come home with her son to the US.
